**Where**
<!-- What module, script or perldoc URL needs to be fixed? -->
pod/perlfunc.pod

**Description**
<!--  Please describe the documentation issue here. -->
In the description of `oct EXPR`, it says
```
(If EXPR happens to start off with C<0x>, interprets it as a
hex string.  If EXPR starts off with C<0b>, it is interpreted as a
binary string.
```
I think that this should mention `C<x>` and `C<b>` (without leading `0`) also, as current `oct` seems to accept them.

In many places, [perlre](https://metacpan.org/pod/perlre) uses 'match' in a way that implies 'capture'.
Idem [perlvar](https://metacpan.org/pod/perlvar).

I think it would be better if 'match' only means 'match', and that 'capture' means 'match-and-make-the-matched-part-available-in-some-convenient-buffer'.

Example:
```
$^N contains whatever was matched by the
    most-recently closed group (submatch)
```
```
perl5.28.1 -Mstrict -wE'$|=1;
  $_= "  foo  bar  ";
  /(?: foo )/x  and say "a: ", $^N;
  /(?: foo )/x  and say "b: ", $+;
##/(?: foo )/x  and say "c: ", $&; # (slow, see perlvar)
  /(?: foo )/xp and say "d: ", ${^MATCH};
  /(?: foo )/x  and say "e: ", substr($_, $-[0], $+[0] - $-[0]);

  /(   foo )/x  and say "A: ", $^N;
  /(   foo )/x  and say "B: ", $+;
'
```
```
Use of uninitialized value $^N in say at -e line 3.
a: 
Use of uninitialized value $+ in say at -e line 4.
b: 
d: foo
e: foo
A: foo
B: foo
```

**Where**

https://perldoc.perl.org/5.30.1/functions/split.html
**Description**
<!--  Please describe the documentation issue here. -->
## Error in the documentation of split
In the file in perl/pod/perlfunc.pod, line 7844
### old content

    produces the output C<a:bc>, and each of these:
    
        print join(':', split(//, 'abc', 3)), "\n";
        print join(':', split(//, 'abc', 4)), "\n";
    
    produces the output C<a:b:c>.

### new content

    produces the output C<a:bc>, and each of these:
    
        print join(':', split(//, 'abc', 4)), "\n";
        print join(':', split(//, 'abc', 5)), "\n";
    
    produces the output C<a:b:c:>.

[split.pl.txt](https://github.com/Perl/perl5/files/5010540/split.pl.txt)

0

    sleep EXPR
    sleep   Causes the script to sleep for (integer) EXPR seconds, or

First, make sure that what you want to backport is documented.  If it's worth

**Where**
https://metacpan.org/changes/release/XSAWYERX/perl-5.32.0#perlxs

**Description**
It's misleading to say, "Suggest using libffi for simple library bindings." The link is also broken, so this likely causes the interested party in searching cpan for "libffi".

This leads to https://metacpan.org/pod/FFI, where the author says, "NOTE: Newer and better maintained `FFI` modules such as `FFI::Platypus` provide more functionality and so it is strongly recommend that you use one of them for new projects and even consider migrating to one of them for existing projects."

When in fact, the `perlxs` (https://perldoc.perl.org/perlxs.html#Introduction) actually says, "For simple bindings to C libraries as well as other machine code libraries, consider instead using the much simpler libffi interface via CPAN modules like `FFI::Platypus` or `FFI::Raw`."

It is not lost on me that `FFI`'s author is also the author of `FFI::Platypus`.

Consider this program, adapted from `t/op/readline.t` in the Perl 5 core distribution.
```
$ cat rt-19566-readline.pl 
use strict;
use Test::More (tests => 1);

# [perl #19566]: sv_gets writes directly to its argument via
# TARG. Test that we respect SvREADONLY.
use constant roref => \2;
eval { for (roref) { $_ = <FH> } };
like($@, qr/Modification of a read-only value attempted/, '[perl #19566]');
```
We run it.
```
$ perl rt-19566-readline.pl 
1..1
ok 1 - [perl \#19566]
```
All appears well.  But then we think, "What if we ran it with warnings?"
```
$ perl -w rt-19566-readline.pl 
1..1
Name "main::FH" used only once: possible typo at rt-19566-readline.pl line 7.
readline() on unopened filehandle FH at rt-19566-readline.pl line 7.
ok 1 - [perl \#19566]
```
Not one, but **two** warnings are generated.

We fix the first of those warnings by silencing the 'once' category within the smallest appropriate scope.  We then re-run.
```
$ cat rt-19566-readline-1.pl
use strict;
use Test::More (tests => 1);

# [perl #19566]: sv_gets writes directly to its argument via
# TARG. Test that we respect SvREADONLY.
use constant roref => \2;
eval {
    no warnings 'once';
    for (roref) { $_ = <FH> }
};
like($@, qr/Modification of a read-only value attempted/, '[perl #19566]');
$ perl -w rt-19566-readline-1.pl
1..1
readline() on unopened filehandle FH at rt-19566-readline-1.pl line 9.
ok 1 - [perl \#19566]
```
We next look through `perldoc perldiag` for `readline() on unopened filehandle` -- but we don't find it!
```
$ perldoc perldiag | grep -n "readline() on unopened filehandle"
$
```
We loosen the terms of our search a bit.
```
$ perldoc perldiag | grep -n "readline"
4694:    readline() on closed filehandle %s
```
So we get a warning if we call `readline()` on a **closed** filehandle -- but not if we call it on an **unopened** filehandle.

Changing our search terms further:
```
$ perldoc perldiag | grep -n -A1 -E "read.*?(unopened|closed) filehandle"
4694:    readline() on closed filehandle %s
4695-        (W closed) The filehandle you're reading from got itself closed
--
4698:    read() on closed filehandle %s
4699:        (W closed) You tried to read from a closed filehandle.
4700-
4701:    read() on unopened filehandle %s
4702-        (W unopened) You tried to read from a filehandle that was never
--
5394:    sysread() on closed filehandle %s
5395:        (W closed) You tried to read from a closed filehandle.
5396-
5397:    sysread() on unopened filehandle %s
5398-        (W unopened) You tried to read from a filehandle that was never
```
We note that we have documented what happens when you attempt to either `read()` or `sysread()` on an unopened filehandle -- but have overlooked the `readline()` case.

Nonetheless, if we hypothesize that we can silence the warning with `no warnings 'unopened'`, we see that we are in luck.
```
$ cat rt-19566-readline-2.pl
use strict;
use Test::More (tests => 1);

# [perl #19566]: sv_gets writes directly to its argument via
# TARG. Test that we respect SvREADONLY.
use constant roref => \2;
eval {
    no warnings 'once';
    no warnings 'unopened';
    for (roref) { $_ = <FH> }
};
like($@, qr/Modification of a read-only value attempted/, '[perl #19566]');

$ perl rt-19566-readline-2.pl
1..1
ok 1 - [perl \#19566]
```
So we have a functioning warning that lacks documentation.  Pull request to follow.

Thank you very much.
Jim Keenan

Free free to just close this issue without taking any other action. That's probably what I'd do.

----

In https://metacpan.org/pod/release/XSAWYERX/perl-5.32.0/pod/perldelta.pod it says:

> Unicode is in the process of revising its regular expression requirements: https://www.unicode.org/draft/reports/tr18/tr18.html. As part of that they are wanting more properties to be exposed, ones that aren't part of the strict UCD (Unicode character database). These two are used for examining inputs for security purposes. Details on their usage is at https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr39/proposed.html.

* The link for a draft TR18 404s. There's a new TR18 with a publication data 2020-06-17 at https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr18/.

* The link to a TR39 proposal says "There is no proposed update of this technical report available at this time. See the latest version.". The latest version, dated 2020-02-06, is at https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr39/.

----

I'd be happy to do a PR on the perldelta.pod if someone says to do that. Here's what it would be unless someone's input suggests otherwise:

> Unicode has revised its regular expression requirements: L<https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr18/tr18-21.html>. As part of that they are wanting more properties to be exposed, ones that aren't part of the strict UCD (Unicode character database). These two are used for examining inputs for security purposes. Details on their usage is at L<https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr39/>.

----

I found only one match for "Identifier" on the perlunicode page and it didn't seem to be relevant. More generally my guess is that no change, or no change other than the above, is needed in Perl doc.

----

I originally posted about the above on reddit, noting that it was "minutiae". It's quite plausibly a lot less interesting than a typo, and no change is necessary or even desirable. The Unicode consortium switched the TR18 status pretty much simultaneously with the 5.32.0 freeze. So what? It's trivial for folk to guess that the change has now happened. I've only posted this issue because briandfoy essentially directed me to post an issue or do a PR. The perl5 repo fork in the GH XSAWYERX account is from 2014, so I've posted here.

Feel free to just close this issue, and/or point me to the right place if this is the wrong one. Alternatively, I will be happy to do a PR as I explained at the start.  I could well believe that, if any change is needed at all, it's just the above PR. Conversely, if more changes are needed, I would say I'm not the right person to write them.

My apologies to whoever is reading this if it's all just a lot of noise about nothing...

- references to YAPC, which has changed to TPC
- OSCON has been discontinued
- https://www.theperlreview.com/community_calendar is a dead link

perldiag describes an error

- Allocation too large: %x
(X) You can't allocate more than 64K on an MS-DOS machine.

But the old 16-bit MS-DOS port was discontinued a long time ago.  A 32-bit build with DJGPP does not have the 64K limitation.  The code raising the error was removed in commit 39c0d7ee897c13cceed4e2b5712cd4e88315336a but it wasn't removed from the documentation.

Emulated using mandatory locks.  Also note that on this platform, if

blocking exclusive lock on the same file, that process will deadlock.

**Where**
[File::Find](https://metacpan.org/pod/File::Find)

**Description**
```$File::Find::dir``` is described as "the current directory name", however, it is actually the current directory path.

For example, if ```find``` is working in ```Documents/taxes```, the current directory name should be ```taxes```, but ```$File::Find::dir``` returns the full path ```Documents/taxes```.

It is way too late to change that variable name to ```$File::Find::dirpath```, but the doc could be edited to reflect what it really is.

**Where**
<!-- What module, script or perldoc URL needs to be fixed? -->
perldiag perldeprecation
**Description**
<!--  Please describe the documentation issue here. -->
These modules have out-dated text about 5.32, referring to it in the future.  But the future is upon us.

perldata says

> Since you can assign to a list of variables, you can also assign to an array or hash slice ...
> > `@colors{'red','blue','green'} = (0xff0000, 0x0000ff, 0x00ff00);`
> 
> The previous assignments are exactly equivalent to ...
> > `($colors{'red'}, $colors{'blue'}, $colors{'green'}) = (0xff0000, 0x0000ff, 0x00ff00);`

OK, but it needs to mention more than just one depth,
> @{$colors{favorites}}{ 'red', 'blue', 'green' } #OK

Else users will extend the analogy presented, and assume
> `@colors{favorites}{ 'red', 'blue', 'green' } #syntax error`

will work !

Also mention there is no way to use a consistent syntax for first vs.
more layers.

`$ perldoc -f each`
notes that it can now also be used for arrays,
but the examples still are only of hashes.

Here we see some tutorials have leaked out of the tutorials section,
ending up in the next ("Reference Manual") section.

```
$ man perl|col -b|perl -wlne 'next unless /[Tt]utor|Reference/ && (length) < 66; print;'
   Tutorials
           perlretut           Perl regular expressions tutorial
           perlootut           Perl OO tutorial for beginners
           perldebtut          Perl debugging tutorial
   Reference Manual
             perlopentut       Perl open() tutorial
             perlpacktut       Perl pack() and unpack() tutorial
           perlthrtut          Perl threads tutorial
           perlunitut          Perl Unicode tutorial
           perlxstut           Perl XS tutorial
```
Therefore, the "perl" man page needs fixing.

perldata says
>Starting in Perl 5.20, a hash slice operation with the % symbol is a variant of slice operation returning a list of key/value pairs rather than just values:
```
            %h = (blonk => 2, foo => 3, squink => 5, bar => 8);
            %subset = %h{'foo', 'bar'}; # key/value hash slice...
```
>However, the result of such a slice cannot be ... used in assignment.


Well you just did, at %subset = ...
So perhaps rewrite that paragraph.

perlsyn mentions
```
 for (@ary) { s/foo/bar/ }
```
but it doesn't mention that this can also be written
```
s/foo/bar/ for @ary;
```
a fact that certainly should be mentioned there on perl**syn**!

(Sure, it is already mentioned on some other man page, that nobody can
find, as which page it is is not mentioned there on perlsyn's for/foreach discussion.)

OK, once that is fixed we note that perlsyn also mentions
```
for my $elem (@elements) {
           $elem *= 2;
   }
```
which we will now know can also be written
```
$elem *= 2 for my $elem @elements;
```
But of course that is a **syntax** error, and perl**syn** doesn't say how to
write it properly, or if it can be written at all.

http://www.wall.org/~larry/perl.html

**Where**
https://perldoc.pl/open.html

**Description**
Please provide more examples how to combine subpragmas

I have tried:
```
use open ':std :utf8'; 
use open IO => ':std :utf8'; 
```

When actually should:

```
use open ':encoding(UTF-8)', ':std';
```

<!--
Note: you can also replace the whole content with a file generated by the perlbug utility;
perlbug reports by email are no longer supported.
-->

<!--
If your bug is about a Perl core module rather than a core language
feature, please enter its name after.
-->
Module: Data::Dumper

**Description**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->

Docs for `$Data::Dumper::Indent` read:

> Style 2 (the default) outputs a very readable form which takes into account the length of hash keys (so the hash value lines up).

However, either I don't understand the intent of "value lines up" (which I gather should be "values line up"?), or they don't.

**Steps to Reproduce**
<!-- A one-liner or script to reproduce the issue. -->

```
$ perl -e 'use Data::Dumper;print Dumper({a=>1,aa=>2,aaa=>3}),"\n"'
$VAR1 = {
          'aaa' => 3,
          'a' => 1,
          'aa' => 2
        };
```


**Expected behavior**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen. -->

With values lined up, I'd expect to see something like:

```
$VAR1 = {
          'aaa' => 3,
          'a'   => 1,
          'aa'  => 2
        };
```

**Where**
`perlre`, `perlretut`


**Description**
<!--  Please describe the documentation issue here. -->

`perlretut` [warns that](https://metacpan.org/release/perl/source/pod/perlretut.pod#L1686)
> Currently, the `\G` anchor is only fully supported when used to anchor to the start of the pattern.

whlie `perlre` provides [an example](https://metacpan.org/release/perl/source/pod/perlre.pod#L1104) showing `\G` being used at the end of a pattern:
```
while ($string =~ /(.\G)/g) {
    print $1;
}
```
without a similar warning.

There's no description of what _not_ "fully supported" entails, and the example in `perlre` unaccompanied by a similar warning implies that it _is_ fully supported.

**Where**
<!-- What module, script or perldoc URL needs to be fixed? -->

the **Assignment Operators** section of the perlop documentation (either from running `perldoc perlop` or visiting http://perldoc.perl.org/5.30.0/perlop.html#Assignment-Operators)

**Description**
<!--  Please describe the documentation issue here. -->

This section documents the return value of a list assignment in list context, and of a list assignment in scalar context, but does not say anything about the return value of a scalar assignment.

I presume this return value is the value of the scalar assigned, as this would seem to be the mechanism that allows something like `$a = $b = $c = 5` to assign 5 to all three variables:

    perl -e '$a = $b = $c = 5; print "$a $b $c\n";'

This should be mentioned in this section of perlop.  Thanks for considering this.

**Where**
`perlunicode`

**Description**
There are several mentions of “the UTF8 flag” in `perlunicode` whose presence seems to contradict the exhortation to ignore that same flag in `perlunifaq`.

**Where**
https://perldoc.pl/perlpacktut#Another-Portable-Binary-Encoding

**Description**
perlpacktut refers to a "Scarab project" at casbah.org which no longer seems to exist. I can't find any explanatory websites other than the archived site: https://web.archive.org/web/20080517124048/http://www.casbah.org/

Originally posted at https://github.com/OpusVL/perldoc.perl.org/issues/99

Perlop says
```
   Relational Operators
       Perl operators that return true or false generally return values that can be safely used as numbers.  For
       example, the relational operators in this section and the equality operators in the next one return 1 for
       true and a special version of the defined empty string, "", which counts as a zero but is exempt from
       warnings about improper numeric conversions, just as "0 but true" is.
```
Perhaps add
```
If you want a real 0, then add 0 to it.
   print 3 == 3; # 1
   print 3 == 4; # nothing
   print 0 + ( 3 == 4 ); # 0

piconv man page says:

       -f,--from from_encoding
           Specifies the encoding you are converting from.  Unlike iconv, this option can be omitted.  In such
           cases, the current locale is used.

       -t,--to to_encoding
           Specifies the encoding you are converting to.  Unlike iconv, this option can be omitted.  In such
           cases, the current locale is used.

But in most / some / current ? real iconv it can also be omitted. So say "in **some** implementations of iconv...'

           Therefore, when both -f and -t are omitted, piconv just acts like cat.

Well it actually just prints a usage message.

           next LINE if (1 .. /^$/);  # skip header lines, short for

Actually all the parentheses can be removed from the example.

                                                 # (typically in a loop labeled LINE)

Actually LINE is special. Using e.g., LINEz would need a existing label.

**Where**
https://perldoc.perl.org/perlreref.html under **EXTENDED CONSTRUCTS**

**Description**

* `(*pla:...)`, the synonym for `(?=...)`, is incorrectly shown as `(?*pla:...)`
* `(*nla:...)`, the synonym for `(?!...)`, is incorrectly shown as `(?*nla:...)`
* `(*plb:...)`, the synonym for `(?<=...)`, is incorrectly shown as `(?*plb:...)`
* `(*nlb:...)`, the synonym for `(?<!...)`, is incorrectly shown as `(?*nlb:...)`
* `(*atomic:...)`, the synonym for `(?>...)`, is incorrectly shown as `(?*atomic:...)`

When testing these in Perl v5.30.1, the versions without `?` are the only ones that work. Any attempt to use ones with `?` results in the error `Sequence (?*...) not recognized in regex; marked by <-- HERE in `...

In https://perldoc.perl.org/perlre.html these are already documented correctly.

---

Now, for a proposal: `(?*...)` is currently not mapped to anything in any regex engine [except for mine](https://github.com/Davidebyzero/RegexMathEngine/blob/master/parser.cpp#L408), in which it is **non-atomic** lookahead (a.k.a. [molecular lookahead](https://github.com/Davidebyzero/RegexMathEngine/commit/db4e4a266d55ec66663ccaa17de944508ace4067)). I believe this mapping makes a great deal of sense, and is the best meaning `(?*...)` and `(?<*...)` could have (lookahead and lookbehind, respectively). My rationale:

* The `*` shows that it tries all possibilities when backtracked into, rather than sticking with the first one it finds and being skipped over by backtracking, like regular atomic positive lookarounds do.
* If non-atomic negative lookarounds were needed, that might be an argument for using a symbol that contains `=` for the positive version (for symmetry). But there is no need for negative non-atomic lookarounds, because a negative lookaround that results in a match outside will always have already tried all possibilities the first time it was hit; when backtracking into it, there would be no possibilities left to try, anyway. (As far as PCRE is concerned, a second reason could be given: molecular lookaround is only useful when capture(s) are made inside, and no captures made inside a negative lookaround should survive outside of it. But I realize that in Perl, once a negative lookaround is exited after failing to find any match, thus matching outside, captures made inside of it will contain the last thing they did when it made its last failed match inside.)
* The one case in which a negative non-atomic lookaround might make sense is for lookaround conditionals, because in Perl and PCRE2, a negative lookaround conditional that matches inside (thus failing to match outside) will give its captures from that match to the conditional's negative alternative. However, anything that a negative lookaround conditional can do, a positive one can also do, just by swapping the two alternatives. So the argument holds, that negative non-atomic lookaround is not needed. It's not worth putting one extra character in the symbol for non-atomic positive lookaround just so there can be a symmetric negative non-atomic lookaround conditional.

`(?*...)` and `(?<*...)` have no meaning in any other engine, and are ripe for the taking. And somebody has to take the initiative, otherwise this opportunity for intuitive and useful symbol mapping will just go unused (or worse, used for something less useful).

So, I would argue that in Perl, `(?*...)` and `(?<*...)` should be reserved until non-atomic lookarounds are implemented, and then mapped to those functions when they are.
